abstract.p: Letter from Caroline Ring says it is dangerous for so-called health experts to promote kind of obsessive thinking about food described in Oct 18 article in series on overweight Americans

block.p: It is dangerous for so-called health experts to promote the kind of obsessive thinking about food described in ''No Days Off Are Allowed, Experts Argue'' (''The Fat Epidemic,'' front page, Oct. 18).
It is dangerous for so-called health experts to promote the kind of obsessive thinking about food described in ''No Days Off Are Allowed, Experts Argue'' (''The Fat Epidemic,'' front page, Oct. 18).
Chronic dieting can and does contribute to eating disorders. As a recovered anorexic, I know that when food, exercise and calories never leave your mind, there is something gravely wrong.

Doctors and counselors who tell their patients to defend themselves vigilantly against the desire to eat are teaching them to fear food. They sacrifice their patients' well-being to the oppressive social ideal of extreme thinness. Doctors who care about health know there are better ways to achieve and maintain a healthy weight than learning to think about food as the enemy.
